title: Did Albert Einstein steal the idea for the relativity theory? There are rumors that various scientists published the basic ideas of the relativity theory earlier and Einstein did not cite them at all in his publications. Is this true? - Quora

response.answer_text: Being a mathematician does not make you a “superior intellect” to Einstein. If that were the case, they would have written the papers that Einstein did - and I encourage everybody to read the actual papers themselves instead of looking for Answers on Quora which are naturally limited. Special Relativity is high school math with otherwordly, genius reasoning. So much so, that even Poincare himself did not fully grasp it’s implications when he read it: The Moszkowski Affair So many wrong answers on here (and you’ll notice they don’t have any citations or references). How can Poincare possess a “superior” intellect when he couldn’t even grasp the physical implications of Einstein’s 1905 paper? He might have been a better pure mathematician, but not a better THINKER. In other words he wasn’t “smarter” (however you choose to define intelligence). Major difference. I have written about this in other areas, but the myths persist. The short answer is NO he did NOT steal any ideas. For some reference read Waler Isaacson’s biography: Einstein: His Life and Universe: Walter Isaacson: 9780743264747: Amazon.com: Books Or the even better Abraham Pais scientific biography on Einstein (written for real physicists): Amazon.com: Subtle is the Lord: The Science and the Life of Albert Einstein eBook: Abraham Pais: Kindle Store Or Einstein’s work on Quantum Theory by Douglas Stone: Einstein and the Quantum: The Quest of the Valiant Swabian: A. Douglas Stone, Gabriel Vaughan: 9781491531044: Amazon.com: Books You won’t learn much on Quora other than superficial introductions to the history of ideas. Any earnest treatment must be done by delving into the literature.  Here is his notebook on General Relativity, you can read it yourself (if you can understand it): Einstein's Zurich Notebook Here is a physicist and science historian, John Stachel, on Special Relativity and the issue of citation/priority: Einstein's Discovery of Relativity I encourage you to read Walter Isaacson’s biography on Einstein, where he clearly explains the lineage of ideas that led to the relativity principle. Relativity did not begin with Poincare or Lorentz, but with Galileo. Einstein rederived everything Poincare and Lorentz had done from first principles - the constancy of the speed of light and the supposition that the laws of physics should be the same for all observers. Lorentz was not even the author of the Lorentz transformations. Poincare was the first to write down the correct Lorentz Transformations and yet it is named after Lorentz - it remains a historical puzzle why. Einstein did not NEED Lorentz nor Poincare to reach SR. In theory, all you need for SR is Galilean relativity and Maxwell’s equations, and this is why Lorentz always gave Einstein priority over Special Relativity. Fitzgerald should be given priority of length contraction over Lorentz; and that Special Relativity is innate to Maxwell’s equations themselves. Nobody’s going to be as prolific as Einstein was in today’s academic environment, it is too over saturated. Specialization is mandatory in today’s academic world. Einstein was the last ‘natural philosopher,’ somebody who made seminal, field-shattering contributions to every subset of physics: Statistical Mechanics (Brownian Motion) Thermodynamics (Specific Heat of Solids) Cosmology (General Relativity) Kinematics & Electromagnetism (Special Relativity) Physical Chemistry (Avogrado’s Number/Quantum Vibrations) Condescended Matter Physics (Bose-Einstein statistics/Bose-Einstein Condensates) Quantum Theory (Photo-electric Effect, Spontaneous and Stimulated Emission) Steady State Theory (Quantization of Chaos Theory/Bohr-Sommerfeld Conditions) Astronomy (Gravitational Lensing/Einstein Cross/Einstein-Rosen Bridges) Classical Mechanics (Equivalence Principle) etc. The real question is will we ever get another Einstein any time soon? Between Newton and Einstein (honorable mention to Maxwell) was about 200 years. It maybe another 200 years before we get another Einstein. If anything Einstein is UNDERRATED. Fantasy Physics: Should Einstein Have Won 7 Nobel Prizes? What Is a Boson? Einstein Was the First to Know  He worked 6 days a week as a patent clerk in Bern, Switzerland, doing physics when his supervisors weren’t looking. He had no access to academic libraries, calculators, or fellow scientists to correspond with. He had not read Poincare’s work either. And yet he published 4 papers that changed science. Special Relativity: it was Einstein who derived it from first priciples: The invariance of light (constant)The laws of physics are the same for all observers (iniertial frames)And from this he was able to derive the conservation of energy critical to SR, without which SR makes no sense. Poincare did not do this, Lorentz, did not do this. Lastly, the defining principle of relativity is the principle of reciprocity, an idea Poincare never quite grasped (so much for “superior intellect”) and an idea Lorentz didn’t come to terms with until 1915. 10 years after the fact.  General Relativity was pretty much all Einstein. He got a bit of math help (as in pointing out what recondite branch of math to use for a theory that he was literally building from scratch ) from Marcel Grossman, and Levi-Civita. Einstein taught Hilbert his theory, and published the correct field equations 4 months before Hilbert did: Findings Back Einstein In a Plagiarism Dispute Hilbert’s equations were NOT generally covariant. Moreover, to Einstein had already written down the correct formalism for his field equations back in 1912, 3 years before the “race” to final field equations between him and Hilbert (he hadn’t realized they were in fact already generally covariant). Real scientists regard him as the pinnacle of scientific thought along with the great sir Isaac: BBC News | SCI/TECH | Einstein the greatest

In the case of general relativity the answer is just plain no. Einstein did all the work, and he did nearly all the work in complete isolation, except for the last months of 1915, when he was competing very intensely with Hilbert and Noether to make the final form of the theory. By Nov 1915, he had the vacuum equations, certainly without any input from Hilbert, and he used these to calculate the perihelion advance of mercury (getting the right answer) and the deflection of light from the sun (doubling his earlier answer). These equations he already considered in 1914, but rejected, because of the infamous "hole argument". Einstein realized the hole argument was wrong in 1915, but Hilbert's letters to Einstein still repeat the hole argument nonsense, so Hilbert wasn't further along. That was kind of surprising to me, because I thought the mathematicians would see the hole argument was nonsense immediately. Hilbert in Nov 1915 was rushing to follow, sending Einstein pre-prints with his ideas. The preprints annoy Einstein, who feels that Hilbert has done nothing significantly new. Einstein gets the field equations with sources at the end of 1915, with the term that is controversial, and Hilbert gets the same equation with the same term in a paper at the start of 1916 (in pre-print with Einstein's paper), except Hilbert has the action principle, and Einstein does it from the field equations. Both methods work, but it seems Hilbert made a mistake in the trace term, which wouldn't be significant, except people sometimes say Einstein stole the trace term from Hilbert. This is completely ridiculous--- Einstein found the coefficient of the trace term by insisting that the Bianci identity enforce the conservation of stress-energy in a free-falling frame, while Hilbert found the trace term (with supposedly a wrong coefficient, which he fixed in draft) using the action. So the convention today is that it's Einstein's field equations and it's the Einstein Hilbert action, and this is as it should be. Noether did something else during this competitive phase, she did Noether's theorem. So she wasn't interested in stepping over other people's research, she went and did something new. Which is also as it should be. But one must remember in this particular priority row that Hilbert was coming into the game in 1915, after Einstein had toiled on the equivalence principle and the weak field approximation, after rejecting Nordstrom's scalar theory, after formulating the Entwurf theory (a gauge-fixed crappy version of General Relativity with no elegance and wrong perihelion precession), and after Einstein had already calculated a billion things, with all the physicists thinking he had gone mad. It was only in 1916-1917 that people started to realize his stuff works, and by then, Einstein had moved on the the A/B coefficients and cosmology. Hilbert didn't do much, except find the action (it's not that hard) and try to take over the theory for the mathematicians. He then went on to do a bunch of silly unified theories that didn't work. For special relativity, it's a different story. Here the claims of plagiarism are somewhat more justified. Einstein cited absolutely nobody in his 1905 paper, because he did everything from first principles, so he didn't need to. But he was familiar with Poincare, he read Poincare's 1902 book, which contains some of the rudiments of special relativity. This is a lapse in academic honesty, he should have cited Poincare. He does cite Poincare in 1906 and in later life, he gives most of the credit for the special theory to Lorentz and Poincare. He might be forgiven for this lapse, because Poincare was confused on certain issues, like mass-energy equivalence, and Einstein sorted that out quickly. Also Poincare had a wrong philosophy, and I suppose Einstein didn't want to endorse Poincare's philosophy. Also, Poincare was already famous. But Poincare and Lorentz deserve co-credit for special relativity, as Einstein always acknowledged at the end of his life. Regarding all the other claimants, it's a joke. It's either anti-semitism or just professional jealousy. The idea that Einstein was stealing his main ideas is a joke, because his main ideas were laughed at for decades. Photons were laughed at, even by Niels Bohr, until 1919, when Milliken set out to disprove them, and instead showed the theory works. This was also when Compton scattering was discovered. General Relativity was laughed at until 1919, and even then, it wasn't fully accepted within physics until the 1960s.  Einstein also contributed to quantum mechanics in this period, but it wasn't until the 1920s that his wave-particle duality was considered serious. He promoted Bose and DeBroglie, both of whom were outside the mainstream. This stuff was also laughed at. In the 1920s, Einstein was a reputable respected fellow, but then came modern quantum mechanics, and he rejected the interpretation, and became a pariah again. His stance on quantum mechanics cost him other physicists' respect, but it really is a reasonable position, and it was shared to some extent by deBroglie. Schrodinger also jumped on the bandwagon because Schrodinger was deeply in awe of Einstein, but later regretted he didn't follow Bohr. Bohm showed in the 1950 s that deBroglie's interpretation was viable in a mathematical sense, but the jury is out on hidden variables. Bell showed that hidden variables must be nonlocal, but in light of holography, that's doesn't sound as crazy as it used to. Quantum mechanics could be fundamental and exact, or it could be a statistical description of some deeper thing, we just don't know. We'll find out when a quantum computer works, or doesn't.

These aren’t rumors but well-known and oft-studied allegations. Einstein used the formulas of Lorentz, called them Lorentz transformations (so he wasn’t hiding anything) but did not include a citation. Why? He was working in a patent office and had no access to the library where he would have needed to look up the citations. No internet in those days. Was he stealing the idea? No, not at all. He used a certain formula and did not hide the fact that it was Lorentz’s formula. But Lorentz had no idea what the formula meant, how the mathematics said something about the physical world. That idea, the idea of what the mathematics actually means in the world was Einstein’s contribution, not Lorentz’s. Poincare also played with the same formula but couldn’t figure out what it means physically prior to Einstein. In fact, Poincare probably never really understood Einstein’s physics idea fully, although he was a far better mathematician than Einstein could ever hope to be. A similar thing occurred with general relativity. It looks as if Hilbert actually wrote the correct formula down about a week before Einstein did, but only after conversations where Einstein talked about the ideas and showed Hilbert the preliminary versions he was working on. There is no evidence Einstein ever saw Hilbert’s formula first. Einstein came up with the formula himself without seeing Hilbert’s finished work first (so no issue of a citation could arise.) Hilbert did not grasp what the formula was saying in physics. Einstein did, very well, and at great, excruciating mental effort. Hilbert himself never claimed that he beat Einstein to the theory, despite the fact that he wrote the formula down a week earlier, without understanding the full physics. In fact, Hilbert said something like “Every boy on the streets of Gottingen (Hilbert’s university town) knows more four dimensional geometry than Einstein. But it took the genius of Einstein, alone and himself, to create the general theory of relativity and its meaning.” EDIT: See the comments. Several have pointed out that more recent scholarship has debunked the prior consensus that Hilbert even wrote down the correct equations before Einstein. I believe their evidence. It seems that the article Hilbert sent to a journal a week before Einstein wrote the correct equation down was edited by Hilbert later, prior to actual publication but after he had seen Einstein’s correct equation.

The question reflects a common misunderstanding of Albert Einstein’s role in the development of the theory of relativity. The reason for misunderstanding is that Einstein published not only much original, good work in theoretical physics, but also much explanation, of relativity and of many other matters, for intelligent readers other than physicists. The best, and best-known, example is The Evolution of Physics by Einstein and Leopold Infeld. Because of these writings for the general public, which for many years were by far the best explanations of relativity, popular misunderstanding tends to credit Einstein with the entire discovery of relativity. When one then learns about the contributions of many other mathematicians and physicists to the development of the theory of relativity, it sharply contradicts this misconception. However, Einstein did not plagiarize anything; that would have been impossible because the preceding work was mostly well known to theoretical physicists. Einstein himself stated that he was not particularly good at mathematics. In saying this, he was only comparing himself with other theoretical physicists; he was in fact excellent at math, but the point is that his great discoveries were not mathematical equations giving new insights into the working of the Universe. Einstein’s greatness was the opposite: Einstein primarily found new ways of understanding the Universe, which led to better understanding of the significance to physics of equations derived by others, either before Einstein’s work, on in collaboration with Einstein. Here is an approximate outline of Einstein’s contribution to the theory, and the context that others supplied: Special Relativity:The effects of time dilation and length contraction, including their precise formulas, collectively known as the “Lorentz transformation”, were known for many years before Einstein’s work. However, these effects were considered to be peculiarities of matter and/or electromagnetism, in accordance with Maxwell’s equations, because matter is bound together by electromagnetic forces.Einstein’s great achievement was his discovery that the Lorentz transformation could be entirely derived just from the one postulate that the speed of light (when measured locally) is always the same, uninfluenced by the motion of the source or of the observer relative to each other or to anything else. This implied the fundamental epiphany that the Lorentz transformation is not a funny characteristic of matter or of electromagnetic fields, it is a fundamental property of space-time. (An example of the importance of this change of understanding is in Ron Davis’s answer to If it turned out that photons actually have a very small amount of mass, what would that mean for relativity?.)General Relativity:This discovery by Einstein led Hermann Minkowski to apply the powerful mathematical methods of tensor calculus, previously developed by several mathematicians, to the deeper understanding of special relativity. One reason Minkowski’s work was important was that he introduced the concept of the metric tensor, which replaces the concept of length in Pythagoras’s theorem with the idea of a definition of length that varies from place to place in a space, as e.g. on a curved surface. That concept had been progressively developed by many preceding mathematicians, as is described in Ron Davis’s answer to What was the path that led Einstein to recognize gravity as curved spacetime (and so a "fictitious" force)?.Minkowski’s metric tensor was probably the source of Einstein’s fundamental inspiration, a concept of gravity that involves curved space-time, even though Minkowski’s metric tensor was flat.Other reasons for the importance of Minkowski’s work are the introduction of tensor calculus itself, which was fundamentally important in the development of a self-consistent theory, and the more specific fact it showed, that mass, the source of gravitation in Newton’s theory, had to be generalized to the mass-energy-momentum-stress tensor.Even with these important contributions, Einstein was left with the task of finding an equation that incorporated these ideas, and that yielded a theory of gravitation consistent with observation. That derivation seems to have been a cooperative effort with David Hilbert. While Hilbert may have had more of a hand in that derivation, Hilbert himself acknowledged that the credit for the discovery of the equation belonged to Einstein, because Einstein had had the idea of using those concepts.Einstein never claimed any greater part in the development of the theory of relativity than that described above. He was a great theoretical physicist, but so were the other theoretical physicists and mathematicians who were involved. Einstein stands out in importance because he explained these concepts to the general public in a manner they could understand, which he could do because he had particularly great insight in understanding the physics, as distinct from the mathematics. He therefore promoted understanding and interest in contemporary theoretical physics, and inspired many others to enter the field, including me.

The claim has been made that Einstein ‘stole’ from H. A. Lorentz. This is even part of Nazi propaganda. Indeed, much of special relativity is embedded in Lorentz ‘Theory of Electrons’. However, Lorentz himself knew of Einstein’s work. Lorentz never once claimed that Einstein plagerized his work. I read ‘The Theory of Electrons’ by H. A. Lorentz (1915). There is a free copy somewhere on the Internet. However, I am working with my own hard copy that I bought, used. I also read a monograph written by H. A. Lorentz on ‘Einstein’s relativity’. It is entitled ‘The Einstein Theory of Relativity’ by H. A. Lorentz (1920). So you can see that the claim, ‘Einstein stole from H. A. Lorentz’, is false. It is more stupid than a lie, but it is false either way. Lorentz practically handed off the theory off to Einstein. Lorentz specifically says that Einstein’s relativity is ‘useful’. He says that relativity, invented by Einstein, has many different applications. He also congratulates Einstein for ‘bringing philosophy’ back to physics. Lorentz did not equate philosophy with useless, which many people do. Lorentz claims that he himself never considered the hypothesis that the time that he defines in the Lorentz transformations was a real time. He thought that the time measured by the moving observer was somehow less real than the time in the stationary frame. So Lorentz praised Einstein chiefly for his ontology. Lorentz takes credit for most of what is now called special relativity. However, he comes up with one accomplishment that he attributes to Einstein. Lorentz claims that the central axiom of relativity is ‘reciprocity’. It is the idea that two inertial observers will see the others clocks as running slower than their own. This is often referred to as a paradox in antirelativity propaganda. However, it is appear that Lorentz did not think so. Certainly, we can’t blame Lorentz for not acknowledging Einstein. However, I note that Lorentz did not cite other contenders. The Lorentz transformation was introduced by three people within a year of each other. It is understandable than none of them actually cited the other. Lorentz did not cite Poincare, who presented the Lorentz transformation from Einstein. Poincare may have been inspired by Lorentz. However, Poincare did not cite Lorentz or Einstein. Lorentz, Einstein and Poincare don’t even have a separate list of references. Darwin doesn’t have a separate list of references. They have acknowledgements regarding people that they have worked directly with. They sometimes had a footnote citation, especially when referring to experiments. However, the custom of having a list of references had not been formalized yet. This is something that became conventional later. There was another Lorenz, from Sweden, that put together a sort of relativity. However, he published in Swedish journals only. So maybe the whole gang stole from him. The accusations of relativity plagiarism are baseless. Special relativity was a dust storm ideas blowing in the wind. Einstein packed the dust together. Einstein’s reputation became exaggerated among nonscientists. This is my opinion, of course. His reputation as ‘smartest man in the world’ and ‘inventor of the atom bomb’ is highly exaggerated. However, he was HIGHLY regarded among scientists. His peers thought very highly of him. Even without cutting up his brain! Most scientists thought him creative and brilliant. The scientists that don’t aren’t thinking as scientists in that regard. However, accusations of wrong doing are false. People that call Einstein a thief, a plagerizer, or a murderer (yes, I heard one of those) are false. These accusations of wrong doing come from crazy people, in my opinion.

Literally stated: “There is nothing new under the sun!” Ecclesiastes, 4th century B.C. There is this notion called Stigler’s effect. It states most if not all of the time, the scientist that is credited with innovating or discovering something is usually not the one that credit should go to. How can this be you ask? Science is ruled by politics as much as anything else? Recall the famous Newton vs. Leibnitz war over Calculus! What it amounts to is that (and I know this is shocking) most of the things that were discovered were really discovered by others but the credit is assigned as a matter of convenience. There are countless cases like this: Gauss, Euler, Newton, etc, etc. I was in awe of disbelief when I found out things like the normal distribution which is generally credited to Guass and even called a Gaussian, was infact traced back to other scientists living around his time in Europe. Euler’s equations, the same story.. Not Euler.. no way!.. but unfortunately it is true. So the Einstein thing doesn’t surprise me too much. This phenomenon called Stigler’s effect has been going on since the beginning of time. Here is a brief list of Stigler’s law examples. Warning, this may destroy your world so read on your own discretion! List of examples of Stigler's law - Wikipedia It could just be because back then that’s how things worked. This is why getting credit and recognition for your work even in science is not an easy task. It is really a fight for fame. Remember that Einstein was a rock star, he had fame. Due to Stigler’s effect (Even that was attributed to someone before Stigler proving Stigler’s own theory! lol), Even Jesus may not have been the real Jesus! .. lol

Lorentz transformation was indeed derived by some scientists before Einstein. First one was Voigt who derived in 1887 the transformation over which Maxwell equation is invariant. Larmor derived the same formula in 1897. Lorentz derived the formula in 1899. In addition, a mathematician Poincaré came out with the same transformation in 1905 shortly before Einstein. Lorentz transformation was known to theoretical physicist as the formula to maintain Maxwell equation invariant, at the time Einstein submitted his own paper. In my understanding, Einstein did not steal the idea. Independently, Einstein derived Lorentz transformation on his principle of physics he postulated. As a matter of fact, he was not a professional physicist in those days when he was building up his own theory of relativity. He was a bureaucrat working for Patent Agency, who liked to spend his pastime to study physics. For that reason, he did not know of the works by Lorentz and Poincaré. Lorentz and Einstein started their derivation from different standpoints. Lorentz found the transformation over which Maxwell equation is invariant. As you know, Maxwell equation is manipulated into wave equation in the form: (∇2−1c2∂2∂t2)E=0.(∇2−1c2∂2∂t2)E=0. The wave equation includes operators called d’Alembertian operator, which actually is the operators inside the parenthesis. Instead of the symbols [x,y,z,t][x,y,z,t] (first three are for spatial coordinate and the last for time), if we use [x,y,z,w][x,y,z,w] where w = ictict (ii denotes the unit of imaginary number); the d’Alembertian operator is rewritten as 4-dimensional Laplacian operator. In other words, electromagnetic wave equation is a 4-dimentsional Laplace equation. Similar to Laplace equation being invariant over coordinate rotation, Maxwell equation is invariant over 4-dimensional coordinate rotation. The 4-dimensional coordinate rotation some scientists found was Lorentz transformation. On the other hand, Einstein started from his own postulation of principle of constant speed of light. His new idea was based on the unexpected observation in Michaelson-Morley experiment. Despite the different start point, Einstein derived the same transformation that some scientists derived before him. In Lorentz’ style staring from invariance of Maxwell equation, Lorentz transformation can predict the principle of constant speed of light. Conversely, in Einstein’s style starting from the principle of constant speed of light, Lorentz transformation can prove the invariance of Maxwell equation.

There is no such thing as an original idea. Throughout human history, men steal other men’s ideas an claim the ideas as their own. They legalize their claims using western legal systems and patent laws, trademark laws, and copyright laws. For example Newton (1642 -1726) did not “discover” gravity. He simply used math to describe his observations about objects at rest, falling objects and for every action (force) there is a equal an opposite reaction. Newton then used math to explain why the moon orbits the earth and doesn’t fly off into space. All these observations were made by many men (no women?) hundreds to a thousand of years before Newton. In the 4th century BC, the Aristotle (the Greek Philosopher) believed that there was no effect or motion without a cause. The same idea of Newton’s 1st Law. In De Architecture, a ten volumn book written by many authors around 15 BC, the Roman engineer and architect Vitruvius (70BC ~ 10AD) states that gravity is not dependent on a substance’s weight but on the nature of the substance a concept we understand today as specific gravity. Aryabhata, a 5th century Indian mathematician, developed geocentric solar system with eccentric elliptical model of the planets. Brahmagupta (598-670) an Indian astronomer and mathematician described gravity as an attractive force and used the term gurutvakarsan gravity, a thousand years before Newton. Johannes Kepler (1571 - 1630), a German astronomer, mathematician and astrologer was well known for his laws of planetary motion and provideed the foundation for Newton’s work. The same applies to inventions like the light bulb, the electric car (especially the Tesla), the steam engine. SpaceX’s Falcon Rocket is based on Russian scientist Konstantin Tsiolkovsky 1903 rocket equation. The same equation had been derived in 1813 by the British mathematician William Moore. Elon Musk’s SpaceX Merlin Engine is a pintle engine used in the Apollo Program in the lunar lander. It was developed in the late 1950s and early 1960s by Caltech’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory at US taxpayers expense. And the lithium-ion batteries used in the Tesla car were first proposed by a British chemist M Stanley Whittingham in while he worked for Exxon in the 1970s. Today, the Tesla Lithium-ion batteries are built by Panasonic using a Panasonic patented design.

I have to take exception to one assertion by Mr. Heisenberg above. He states that SR was based on two principles, relativity and the constancy of the speed of light. But in his original paper, Einstein did not explicitly begin with the latter as a proposition. What he clearly stated was that the speed of light is independent of the motion of its source. As pointed out by Isaacson in his book on Einstein, it is only when this is combined with the relativity principle that one concludes that the speed of light is independent of the motion of observers; i.e. the same in all inertial reference frames. Thus, the constancy of the speed of light actually follows as a corollary of Einstein's two propositions. Unfortunately, nearly all textbooks and explanations that I've seen make this same error. Does it matter? At one level, no; one can start with the constancy of the speed of light and proceed to derive the Lorentz transformation. But at another level, I think it matters very much. For the question that the inquiring mind asks is how did Einstein come up with this idea of the constancy of the speed of light, which is so different-indeed alien- relative to all known previous wave phenomena? And the answer is he didn't. As pointed out by Isaacson, once Einstein abandoned the notion of an aether, he had to figure what one could say about the speed of light and decided to deal with it by thinking of light speed relative to sources (not observers). One has only two choices: either it depends on the motion of the source or it doesn't. The problem with the former is that it is contradicted by observation, as was discussed in books given to Einstein when he was growing up (see Isaacson's discussion), but even more important, it made a hash of Maxwell's Equations which Einstein apparently found unacceptable. He therefore went with the proposition that the speed of light does not depend on the motion of sources, from which it immediately follows that it also cannot depend on the motion of observers in inertial frames since that would then violate the relativity principle if one switched frames of reference. Personally, I never understood how Einstein came up with his idea of the constancy of the speed of light until it was explained by Isaacson's (the book by Pais, ostensibly written for physicists, does not discuss this at all whereas Isaacson, a non-scientist, clarifies the issue).

I can observe how something acts in nature and come up with a formula that fits the data. However, if I can’t explain WHY the formula works other than to say it fits the data, although I have contributed to our knowledge - in some cases enormously - I have not “solved” the problem. An equation based on experimental data that “works” doesn’t explain why it works, even if it is the right equation. Its the explanation and how it is derived from first principles that truly advances scientific knowledge. Dirac used math to predict the existence of the positron. There was no knowledge of its existence but Dirac’s equations showed it had to exist. In fact it turned out others had actually seen positrons in their experiments but didn’t recognize them for what they were. When positrons, and other antimatter particles were found Nobel prizes were awarded to the experimentalists. But no one would argue it wasn’t Dirac (who also won a Nobel for his work) that deserved the credit for showing why they MUST be there in the first place. Maxwell too built on the contributions of so many who came before him when he developed his eponymous equations. But he explained the why and derived them from first principles and therefore is considered among the greatest minds in physics. I do not mean to minimize the tremendous work done by experimentalists. Their contributions throughout history have been immense. But I am always more impressed by the people who confidently, and correctly, state something MUST be so because their equations tell them it must be so. Or as Einstein put it so succinctly in 1919 when, following the confirmation of general relativity he was asked, ‘what if the facts had not confirmed his theory?’ 'In that case, I'd have felt sorry for God, because the theory is correct'. Those that preceded him came up with formulas that fit the data e.g. the Lorenz formula. But they got the why wrong. They couldn’t explain from first principles why the formula worked, or what it actually was telling them. Einstein did. By the way, those who say he was not very good at mathematics are comparing him to pure mathematicians. If you’ve ever tried to ‘grok’ General Relativity you’d know he was pretty good at it. That was not his field and he didn’t have the breadth and depth of mathematical knowledge a pure mathematician does. But once someone such as his friend Grossman pointed him in the right direction he knew how to use it. More importantly, he understood and could explain to others what it was telling him about the universe and how it works.

Quite a range of answers and opinions.  How interesting it is that two intelligent humans can read the same material and take away entirely different perspectives on "what is truth." While I myself have pointed out in several posts how Einstein's erroneous assumptions led to unnecessary postulation, it cannot be argued that in 1905 he was working blind as to the real construction of the universe.  The titanic change Einstein brought about was not in the math but in the interpretation - the courageous pronouncement that time does not pass at the same rate for all observers.  The arithmetic had already been perfected by Lorentz, the revolution was not in the equations, but what they meant.    The fact that Einstein failed to cite the works of others - could in my mind, be justified in the sense, that the 1905 publication was entirely new from the interpretative context...so much so that it rightly deserved to stand alone. The novelty lay in discovering the workings of nature at a fundamental level - the equations already existed, but they were impotent and confusing without his revolutionary slant. ....  citations would likely have had the effect of diminishing the magnitude of the step he alone realized and understood- so he re-derived them with the idea of making the formalism complete.    Years later (1929) he was asked to write a few short pages expressing his philosophy of life.  One sentence comes to mind:  "Many times a day I am bothered by the thought I have borrowed too heavily from the work of others."

Science is a collective endeavour. Scientists don’t steal their predecessors’ efforts, they verify them, extend them, build upon them. Einstein, in particular, said that “[he] stood on the shoulders of James Clerk Maxwell - Wikipedia”—that doesn’t mean that he stole his work; that means that Maxwell’s work was a prerequisite and inspiration for his (Einstein’s) work. Scientists are people too, with all our faults, of course. But ideally, scientists should not be jealous or offended if somebody corrects or falsifies their work or beats them in getting results. And if their work serves as basis for acquiring further understanding of the ways of nature (by somebody else), they’re proud, not sulky.

The fact that Einstein used well-established mathematical methods is not “stealing”.
